item.title: Twitch Is Making Big Changes To Its Monetization Policies In 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/twitch-is-making-big-changes-to-its-monetization-policies-in-2025/1100-6529764/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Streaming platform Twitch has announced a big change to its monetization policy, as "most streamers" will soon gain access to the site's monetization tools. Previously, only Twitch affiliates and partners could access these revenue-generating tool, but these will be available to more creators later in 2025.

"We want you to be able to take advantage of our monetization tools, whether you're just getting your community started, or have been on Twitch for a while," Twitch CEO Dan Clancy wrote in a blog post. "We're excited to open up monetization tools--subscriptions and bits--to most streamers, from day one. This will allow creators, regardless of their status, to grow their communities and start building earnings through direct patronage. We're also introducing an option, which will allow all streamers to use their earnings on purchases within Twitch."

Previously, earning a Twitch partnership required a user to have 50 followers, an average of three viewers per stream, and at least eight hours of cumulative streaming across at least seven different days. That process could be daunting for new streamers given the competitive nature of Twitch, but it was generally achievable if a person was consistent with their efforts.

Beyond this big change, Clancy also explained other plans for Twitch in 2025. The company is working on features to help partners earn more money while collaborating, both landscape and vertical video through enhanced broadcasting tools will be added to improve the mobile viewing experience, and the tools to edit clips will also be improved. These updates come shortly after Twitch announced that it'll be implementing a 100-hour storage cap on highlights and uploads starting April 19, a move that has not gone over well with a large part of its userbase.

While the company cites a need to save on storage costs and video highlights not being as popular as it envisioned as reasons behind the move, users have noted that Twitch's parent company Amazon is one of the biggest names in cloud storage, leading to criticism of the cost-cutting measure.

Darryn Bonthuys on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Explore Your Own Vision Of The Fallout Wasteland With This Virtual Tabletop RPG Bundle
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/explore-your-own-vision-of-the-fallout-wasteland-with-this-virtual-tabletop-rpg-bundle/1100-6529738/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Fallout has never been more popular thanks to Amazon's recent well-received streaming series, but fans will have to wait a bit longer until Season 2 airs--and who knows how long we'll have to wait to see a new Fallout video game. Luckily, there are other ways to explore the nuclear wasteland in the meantime, and one of the best is the official Fallout tabletop roleplaying game. Like other tabletop RPGs, Fallout: The Roleplaying Game provides a flexible game system for ground friends to create their own adventures set in the Fallout universe--and if that sounds like a good time, you'll want to check out Humble's new Fallout: The Roleplaying Game The Complete Collection bundle, which includes digital versions of the game's various rulebooks, expansions, and quest modules that you can use in the Alchemy virtual tabletop software.

Like other Humble bundles, this is a pay-what-you-want deal, and the more you pay, the more items you get, and A portion of all sales is also donated to charity. For this Fallout TTRPG bundle, Humble has teamed up with Direct Relief to support those affected by the recent wildfires in California.

The bundle starts at just $1, which gets you Alchemy Tabletop versions of the Fallout: The Roleplaying Game Core Rulebook Enhanced Edition and Starter Set. These are the bare minimum materials you need to learn how to play and craft your own adventures, but if you pay $10, you'll get the Settler's Guide Book, Wanderer's Guide Book, and Gamemaster's Tool Kit, all of which expand the game with new rules, character building options, and campaign ideas. You also get the Winter of Atom quest book, which gamemasters can use to guide players through a pre-made storyline.

The full bundle is the best value, packing $244 worth of content for just $18. It gets you everything from the previous tiers, plus five more official quest books, two map packs featuring illustrated maps based on numerous iconic locations from the Fallout games, and four NPC packs--including a pack featuring stats and information for adding the characters from the Fallout TV series to your campaigns.

You'll find the full list of all the books, quests, and gameplay materials included in the Fallout: The Roleplaying Game Complete Collection at Humble. While you only need to pay $18 to get the full collection, you can also pay more if you want to increase your donation to Direct Relief, and you're able to adjust how much of your purchase goes to Humble, Direct Relief, and Alchemy Tabletop before check out. All the materials you get in the bundle are redeemed through the Alchemy Virtual Tabletop service, which is free to join and use. It also includes a storefront to add official materials from other tabletop games to your Alchemy library, including Fallout: The Roleplaying Game, Pathfinder, Vampire: The Masquerade, Dune: Adventures in the Imperium, and more.

It's worth noting that you can also get physical editions of the Fallout RPG books. Fallout: The Roleplaying Game's Core Rulebook is available in hardcover for $44.53 (was $55) at Amazon. You can pair the Core Rulebook with the official Starter Set for $34.63.

Humble has several other bundle deals available right now, including more virtual tabletop offerings like the Dungeon Master Essentials, More Tabletop & RPG Resources, and War of Shadows STL and Ruleset bundles, which offer various digital materials for war gaming and tabletop RPGs, including system-agnostic roll tables and 3D-printable models. You can also grab collections of digital rulebooks for specific games like the Runequest Encore Book Bundle or the Pathfinder Kingmaker Mixed Bundle that includes a key for Pathfinder: Kingmaker Enhanced Plus Edition on Steam alongside dozens of official Pathfinder 2E books, maps, adventure packs, and more. There's also the Pathfinder and Starfinder Comics Bundle that includes up to 71 digital comics set in the Pathfinder and Starfinder universes.

More Humble Tabletop RPG Bundles

  • Dungeon Master Essentials Miniatures & Scenery Bundle
  • More Tabletop & RPG Resources Bundle
  • Pathfinder: Kingmaker Game & Book Mixed Bundle
  • Pathfinder & Starfinder Comics Bundle
  • Runequest Encore Book Bundle
  • War of Shadows STL and Ruleset Bundle

item.title: EA "Won't Rule Out" Returning To College Basketball After Success Of College Football
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/ea-wont-rule-out-returning-to-college-basketball-after-success-of-college-football/1100-6529761/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

EA Sports College Football 25 was the biggest sports game ever in the US according to Circana, and it seems that the publisher is considering bringing back its take on college basketball, which has been dormant for more than a decade. In a recent report from The Athletic, EA Sports senior vice president Daryl Holt said that college basketball (and other sports) remain a possibility, but reiterated that American football is still the publisher's main priority.

"There was a clear need, want, desire from our community and the faithful were there [for college football]," Holt said. “As developers, we try to figure out how we can get creative on reaching other aspects of sports, whether that be a smaller sport or one that doesn't have a game. But right now, my focus has been on American football. We'll keep looking for those things, but as a developer and working in sports, you're always tapping your head going, what else could be possible?”

The last EA Sports-published NCAA basketball game, NCAA Basketball 10, came out in 2009 and featured the now-retired dunk contest champ Blake Griffin as the cover athlete. While any plans for a new college basketball game remain quite nascent, it's likely that EA would try to get as many student athletes as possible to sign to a name, image, and likeness (NIL) deal. More than 11,000 FBS football players opted into CFB 25's deal last year, receiving $600 and a copy of the game as compensation for their NIL rights. The NIL deal for CFB 26 is reportedly still being negotiated, though EA declined to comment on those plans. The CFB series itself lay dormant for more than a decade, the last release coming in 2012 before last year's revival restored its fortunes.

Holt teased new features coming to this year's sequel, CFB 26, including possible improvements to the single-player career mode Road to Glory. CFB 25 was the second-best selling game of 2024 in the US, second only to Call of Duty: Black Ops 6.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
